values.description:
When using cameras for running vision algorithms, the frame rate is often a very important parameter. If the simulated cameras do not provided precisely the expected frame rate, the algorithms are likely to be lost.

Besides, current implementation of cameras highly depends on the CPU/GPU performance of the host machine when the simulation is running. That means that the frame rate cannot be predicted and that the simulations using camera(s) are not repeatable.

The changes proposed in this pull request allows the cameras to run at the desired frame rate whatever the GPU/CPU available on the host. The idea is to put on hold the world update when we need to wait for a camera sensor that requires the current state of the world.

Much care has been taken to avoid wasting time in waiting for nothing. In particular, the threads "world update" and "sensors" are waken up as soon as they can continue their job.

It is possible to go back to the legacy working mode by setting the flag "strict_rate" to false in camera's parameters.

This pull request comes with two other changes located in ignition-math and sdformat:
* https://bitbucket.org/ignitionrobotics/ign-math/pull-requests/134
* https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/pull-requests/289
values.title: Make sure camera's FPS is strictly applied, should the real time factor be impacted

summary.raw:
When using cameras for running vision algorithms, the frame rate is often a very important parameter. If the simulated cameras do not provided precisely the expected frame rate, the algorithms are likely to be lost.

Besides, current implementation of cameras highly depends on the CPU/GPU performance of the host machine when the simulation is running. That means that the frame rate cannot be predicted and that the simulations using camera(s) are not repeatable.

The changes proposed in this pull request allows the cameras to run at the desired frame rate whatever the GPU/CPU available on the host. The idea is to put on hold the world update when we need to wait for a camera sensor that requires the current state of the world.

Much care has been taken to avoid wasting time in waiting for nothing. In particular, the threads "world update" and "sensors" are waken up as soon as they can continue their job.

It is possible to go back to the legacy working mode by setting the flag "strict_rate" to false in camera's parameters.

This pull request comes with two other changes located in ignition-math and sdformat:
* https://bitbucket.org/ignitionrobotics/ign-math/pull-requests/134
* https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/pull-requests/289
summary.html:
When using cameras for running vision algorithms, the frame rate is often a very important parameter. If the simulated cameras do not provided precisely the expected frame rate, the algorithms are likely to be lost.

Besides, current implementation of cameras highly depends on the CPU/GPU performance of the host machine when the simulation is running. That means that the frame rate cannot be predicted and that the simulations using camera(s) are not repeatable.

The changes proposed in this pull request allows the cameras to run at the desired frame rate whatever the GPU/CPU available on the host. The idea is to put on hold the world update when we need to wait for a camera sensor that requires the current state of the world.

Much care has been taken to avoid wasting time in waiting for nothing. In particular, the threads "world update" and "sensors" are waken up as soon as they can continue their job.

It is possible to go back to the legacy working mode by setting the flag "strict_rate" to false in camera's parameters.

This pull request comes with two other changes located in ignition-math and sdformat: https://bitbucket.org/ignitionrobotics/ign-math/pull-requests/134 https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/pull-requests/289

values.description:
Some changes looked trivial to me, there were a couple of memory leaks in the tests since we were using raw pointers.

I've enable the `noExplicitConstructor` globally until we release gazebo8. [I found a weird false positive](#!/osrf/gazebo/pull-requests/new#Lgazebo/common/MovingWindowFilter.hhT69). If I isolate the code and remove the namespaces, cppcheck is happy. If I enable the namespaces again, the warning appears. 

Thanks to Steve for mentioning it we are starting to use the inline cppcheck suppressions (enabled via comment). They have the tradeoff of making the code a bit less readable.
values.title: Clean cppcheck result in Xenial

summary.raw:
Some changes looked trivial to me, there were a couple of memory leaks in the tests since we were using raw pointers.

I've enable the `noExplicitConstructor` globally until we release gazebo8. [I found a weird false positive](#!/osrf/gazebo/pull-requests/new#Lgazebo/common/MovingWindowFilter.hhT69). If I isolate the code and remove the namespaces, cppcheck is happy. If I enable the namespaces again, the warning appears. 

Thanks to Steve for mentioning it we are starting to use the inline cppcheck suppressions (enabled via comment). They have the tradeoff of making the code a bit less readable.
summary.html:
Some changes looked trivial to me, there were a couple of memory leaks in the tests since we were using raw pointers.

I've enable the noExplicitConstructor globally until we release gazebo8. I found a weird false positive. If I isolate the code and remove the namespaces, cppcheck is happy. If I enable the namespaces again, the warning appears.

Thanks to Steve for mentioning it we are starting to use the inline cppcheck suppressions (enabled via comment). They have the tradeoff of making the code a bit less readable.

values.description:
Continuing the effort to remove worlds, history:

* Remove blank world: pull request #2220
* Remove world with entities: pull request #2263
* Remove world with joints: pull request #2309

The previous PRs added tests to `INTEGRATION_remove_worlds`. With the help of @caguero, we noticed that Gazebo was being shutdown when the world was removed, which should not happen.

In order to be able to completely remove a world and then load a new one (issue #158), the Server must outlive worlds.

This pull request is mainly about the change in `gazebo/Server.cc` to avoid shutdown. Other changes to support that:

* cleaning up pointers
* cleaning up transport
* Add `sensors::running()`
* considerably speed up world_remove tests: [9.5s](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/main/view/CI%20any%20jobs/job/gazebo-ci-pr_any-trusty-amd64-gpu-nvidia/761/testReport/(root)/WorldRemoveTest_WorldRemoveTest/) instead of [40s](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/main/view/GazeboDefault/job/gazebo-ci-default-trusty-amd64-gpu-nvidia/253/testReport/(root)/WorldRemoveTest_WorldRemoveTest/) and [37s](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/main/view/CI%20any%20jobs/job/gazebo-ci-pr_any-trusty-amd64-gpu-nvidia/761/testReport/(root)/RemoveJointTypes_WorldRemoveJointsTest/) instead of [2min28s](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/main/view/GazeboDefault/job/gazebo-ci-default-trusty-amd64-gpu-nvidia/253/testReport/(root)/RemoveJointTypes_WorldRemoveJointsTest/)


Trusty nvidia is [satisfied](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/main/view/CI%20any%20jobs/job/gazebo-ci-pr_any-trusty-amd64-gpu-nvidia/761/) (warnings have been fixed in 67c654c)
values.title: Don't shut down gazebo when removing a world -> 8

summary.raw:
Continuing the effort to remove worlds, history:

* Remove blank world: pull request #2220
* Remove world with entities: pull request #2263
* Remove world with joints: pull request #2309

The previous PRs added tests to `INTEGRATION_remove_worlds`. With the help of @caguero, we noticed that Gazebo was being shutdown when the world was removed, which should not happen.

In order to be able to completely remove a world and then load a new one (issue #158), the Server must outlive worlds.

This pull request is mainly about the change in `gazebo/Server.cc` to avoid shutdown. Other changes to support that:

* cleaning up pointers
* cleaning up transport
* Add `sensors::running()`
* considerably speed up world_remove tests: [9.5s](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/main/view/CI%20any%20jobs/job/gazebo-ci-pr_any-trusty-amd64-gpu-nvidia/761/testReport/(root)/WorldRemoveTest_WorldRemoveTest/) instead of [40s](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/main/view/GazeboDefault/job/gazebo-ci-default-trusty-amd64-gpu-nvidia/253/testReport/(root)/WorldRemoveTest_WorldRemoveTest/) and [37s](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/main/view/CI%20any%20jobs/job/gazebo-ci-pr_any-trusty-amd64-gpu-nvidia/761/testReport/(root)/RemoveJointTypes_WorldRemoveJointsTest/) instead of [2min28s](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/main/view/GazeboDefault/job/gazebo-ci-default-trusty-amd64-gpu-nvidia/253/testReport/(root)/RemoveJointTypes_WorldRemoveJointsTest/)


Trusty nvidia is [satisfied](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/main/view/CI%20any%20jobs/job/gazebo-ci-pr_any-trusty-amd64-gpu-nvidia/761/) (warnings have been fixed in 67c654c)
summary.html:
Continuing the effort to remove worlds, history:

  • Remove blank world: pull request #2220
  • Remove world with entities: pull request #2263
  • Remove world with joints: pull request #2309

The previous PRs added tests to INTEGRATION_remove_worlds. With the help of @caguero, we noticed that Gazebo was being shutdown when the world was removed, which should not happen.

In order to be able to completely remove a world and then load a new one (issue #158), the Server must outlive worlds.

This pull request is mainly about the change in gazebo/Server.cc to avoid shutdown. Other changes to support that:

  • cleaning up pointers
  • cleaning up transport
  • Add sensors::running()
  • considerably speed up world_remove tests: 9.5s instead of 40s and 37s instead of 2min28s

Trusty nvidia is satisfied (warnings have been fixed in 67c654c)

values.description: Create ode physics parameter `ode_quiet`, which cause all ode dMessage's to not be printed (the world solver in particular prints lots of messages). This parameter is set during the `RevoluteJoint` test when the `world_step` solver is used, since that test generates [excessive console output](https://gist.github.com/scpeters/da138a8a8a1208bf89447baf2b49b10f). I also added it to the FrictionDemo test that uses `world_step`.
values.title: Create ode parameter to silence solver messages

summary.raw: Create ode physics parameter `ode_quiet`, which cause all ode dMessage's to not be printed (the world solver in particular prints lots of messages). This parameter is set during the `RevoluteJoint` test when the `world_step` solver is used, since that test generates [excessive console output](https://gist.github.com/scpeters/da138a8a8a1208bf89447baf2b49b10f). I also added it to the FrictionDemo test that uses `world_step`.
summary.html: Create ode physics parameter ode_quiet, which cause all ode dMessage's to not be printed (the world solver in particular prints lots of messages). This parameter is set during the RevoluteJoint test when the world_step solver is used, since that test generates excessive console output. I also added it to the FrictionDemo test that uses world_step.

values.description:
Support loading materials that have a URI. See the `mesh.mtl` and `model.config` files in [this PR](#!/osrf/gazebo_models/pull-requests/238). 

Moved a mutex in `InsertModelWidget` to prevent deadlock. The deadlock occurs when inserting a model that has a dependency before the model database has established a connection. To try this yourself:

1. Make sure you *do not* have the `walkway_metal_straight` model.
2. Put the [`walkway_metal_90` model](#!/osrf/gazebo_models/pull-requests/238) in your `~.gazebo/models` path.
3. Start gazebo
4. Quickly try to insert the `Walkway metal 90` model from the gui.
5. Deadlock
values.title: Material paths

summary.raw:
Support loading materials that have a URI. See the `mesh.mtl` and `model.config` files in [this PR](#!/osrf/gazebo_models/pull-requests/238). 

Moved a mutex in `InsertModelWidget` to prevent deadlock. The deadlock occurs when inserting a model that has a dependency before the model database has established a connection. To try this yourself:

1. Make sure you *do not* have the `walkway_metal_straight` model.
2. Put the [`walkway_metal_90` model](#!/osrf/gazebo_models/pull-requests/238) in your `~.gazebo/models` path.
3. Start gazebo
4. Quickly try to insert the `Walkway metal 90` model from the gui.
5. Deadlock
summary.html:
Support loading materials that have a URI. See the mesh.mtl and model.config files in this PR.

Moved a mutex in InsertModelWidget to prevent deadlock. The deadlock occurs when inserting a model that has a dependency before the model database has established a connection. To try this yourself:

  1. Make sure you do not have the walkway_metal_straight model.
  2. Put the walkway_metal_90 model in your ~.gazebo/models path.
  3. Start gazebo
  4. Quickly try to insert the Walkway metal 90 model from the gui.
  5. Deadlock

values.description:
part of the work done on osx bundling. 

The rendering engine currently loads ogre plugins based on the `OGRE_RESOURCE_PATH`. However that doesn't work in an osx application bundle. The bundled app should be self-contained without relying on external installation of ogre. So the ogre plugins are pulled into the bundle and there needs to be a way get their path relative to the executable, hence this function is added. 

[Here's the line](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/3819a7b785328e2e21fb118dc5bec235ef94904d/gazebo/common/SystemPaths.cc?at=qt5_bundle_ian&fileviewer=file-view-default#SystemPaths.cc-138) in the `qt5_bundle_ian` branch that uses this function to set up the ogre paths

[homebrew](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/main/view/gazebo/job/gazebo-ci-pr_any-homebrew-amd64/795/) - ok
values.title: Add function to get path to application executable directory

The rendering engine currently loads ogre plugins based on the `OGRE_RESOURCE_PATH`. However that doesn't work in an osx application bundle. The bundled app should be self-contained without relying on external installation of ogre. So the ogre plugins are pulled into the bundle and there needs to be a way get their path relative to the executable, hence this function is added. 

[Here's the line](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/3819a7b785328e2e21fb118dc5bec235ef94904d/gazebo/common/SystemPaths.cc?at=qt5_bundle_ian&fileviewer=file-view-default#SystemPaths.cc-138) in the `qt5_bundle_ian` branch that uses this function to set up the ogre paths

[homebrew](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/main/view/gazebo/job/gazebo-ci-pr_any-homebrew-amd64/795/) - ok

part of the work done on osx bundling.

The rendering engine currently loads ogre plugins based on the OGRE_RESOURCE_PATH. However that doesn't work in an osx application bundle. The bundled app should be self-contained without relying on external installation of ogre. So the ogre plugins are pulled into the bundle and there needs to be a way get their path relative to the executable, hence this function is added.

Here's the line in the qt5_bundle_ian branch that uses this function to set up the ogre paths

homebrew - ok

values.description:
a spinoff from pull request #2485 for improving heightmap performance.

Requires [this sdformat pull request](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/pull-requests/293/add-heightmap-sampling-parameter/diff)

The heightmap sampling param can now be changed via sdf. You can now reduce the level of sampling from the default value of 2 to 1 for faster load time and better framerate. e.g.

~~~
          <geometry>
            <heightmap>
              <uri>file://media/materials/textures/heightmap_bowl.png</uri>
              <size>129 129 10</size>
              <pos>0 0 0</pos>
              <sampling>1</sampling>
            </heightmap>
          </geometry>
~~~

[nvidia-gpu](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/main/view/gazebo/job/gazebo-ci-pr_any-trusty-amd64-gpu-nvidia/771/) - ok

[abi](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-abichecker-any_to_any-xenial-amd64/144/API_ABI_report/) - ok
values.title: Support configuring heightmap sampling level

values.description:
* Deprecating `gazebo::math::Plane` is easy; it isn't even used anywhere

* Deprecating `gazebo::math::Matrix4` is easy too; just switch one instance to ignition::math::Matrix4

* Deprecating `math::clamp` takes a little more work to replace with ignition::math::clamp, but is still not too bad
values.title: Deprecate math::Plane, math::Matrix4, math::clamp

summary.raw:
* Deprecating `gazebo::math::Plane` is easy; it isn't even used anywhere

* Deprecating `gazebo::math::Matrix4` is easy too; just switch one instance to ignition::math::Matrix4

* Deprecating `math::clamp` takes a little more work to replace with ignition::math::clamp, but is still not too bad

values.description:
This deprecates the `gazebo::math::Rand` functions and switches to ignition math functions instead. There are two a few places where `SetSeed` function calls are retained to ensure functionality during this deprecation cycle, but otherwise everything is switched to ignition.

Also:

* dd698a0: I missed a few doxygen deprecation comments in pull request #2522

* 66d9a0e: remove several header includes of gazebo/math/Rand.hh
values.title: Deprecate math::Rand functions

summary.raw:

Also:

values.description:
When setting visual transparency to a non-zero value we currently overwrite certain material pass properties ([scene blending mode](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/2ca5c6f57bd405b90f563d5266a503cc2951bb9f/gazebo/rendering/Visual.cc?at=default&fileviewer=file-view-default#Visual.cc-1500) and [depth write](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/2ca5c6f57bd405b90f563d5266a503cc2951bb9f/gazebo/rendering/Visual.cc?at=default&fileviewer=file-view-default#Visual.cc-1505)) for transparency to work. We do so without remembering the original values so when transparency is turned off, we're not able to restore the material to the original state.

You can reproduce the problem by turning transparency on then off with this [prius](https://www.dropbox.com/s/7d5927vwbf7jlba/prius_hybrid.zip?dl=0) model or the [robocup09_spl_field](#!/osrf/gazebo_models/src/f8f2f9af8a59da5f5c60416a29eecdfae5f90125/robocup09_spl_field/?at=default). In the latter case, the net of the goal causes depth rendering problem when viewing the field from behind the goal.

This PR caches the original material when an object is attached to the visual and uses it to restore the material pass settings when transparency is turned off.

Other couple of minor changes:

- update a few variable default values in common::Material

- fixed loading an OBJ material that does not have a texture file.

jenkins: [nividia-gpu](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/main/view/gazebo/job/gazebo-ci-pr_any-trusty-amd64-gpu-nvidia/799) - ok
values.title: Fix restoring submesh material transparency

summary.raw:
When setting visual transparency to a non-zero value we currently overwrite certain material pass properties ([scene blending mode](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/2ca5c6f57bd405b90f563d5266a503cc2951bb9f/gazebo/rendering/Visual.cc?at=default&fileviewer=file-view-default#Visual.cc-1500) and [depth write](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/2ca5c6f57bd405b90f563d5266a503cc2951bb9f/gazebo/rendering/Visual.cc?at=default&fileviewer=file-view-default#Visual.cc-1505)) for transparency to work. We do so without remembering the original values so when transparency is turned off, we're not able to restore the material to the original state.

You can reproduce the problem by turning transparency on then off with this [prius](https://www.dropbox.com/s/7d5927vwbf7jlba/prius_hybrid.zip?dl=0) model or the [robocup09_spl_field](#!/osrf/gazebo_models/src/f8f2f9af8a59da5f5c60416a29eecdfae5f90125/robocup09_spl_field/?at=default). In the latter case, the net of the goal causes depth rendering problem when viewing the field from behind the goal.

This PR caches the original material when an object is attached to the visual and uses it to restore the material pass settings when transparency is turned off.

Other couple of minor changes:

- update a few variable default values in common::Material

- fixed loading an OBJ material that does not have a texture file.

jenkins: [nividia-gpu](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/main/view/gazebo/job/gazebo-ci-pr_any-trusty-amd64-gpu-nvidia/799) - ok
summary.html:
When setting visual transparency to a non-zero value we currently overwrite certain material pass properties (scene blending mode and depth write) for transparency to work. We do so without remembering the original values so when transparency is turned off, we're not able to restore the material to the original state.

You can reproduce the problem by turning transparency on then off with this prius model or the robocup09_spl_field. In the latter case, the net of the goal causes depth rendering problem when viewing the field from behind the goal.

This PR caches the original material when an object is attached to the visual and uses it to restore the material pass settings when transparency is turned off.

Other couple of minor changes:

  • update a few variable default values in common::Material

  • fixed loading an OBJ material that does not have a texture file.

jenkins: nividia-gpu - ok

values.description:
Changes required to run Gazebo with DART 6.

There are still 3 test failures related to DART which may need to be addressed or skipped for DART. The test failures don't seem to suggest anything too severe, but they point out some inaccuracies. This PR is a place to discuss what to do with these tests.

### Test failure 1. JointForceTorqueTest.GetForceTorqueWithAppliedForce (and same for JointForceTorqueTest.GetForceTorqueWithAppliedForceReset)

The cubes are meant to be "held up" by the force set to the joints. When viewing with gzclient, the behaviour is exactly the same as with ODE, it's working as expected. However the force and torque of wrench01 fluctuate quite significantly ([-35..35], sometimes more or less), while they are expected to fluctuate only in the range [-2..2].  The fluctuations aren't smooth, they sometimes incur large jumps between iterations.

Maybe the DART reaction to setting the force does not have an effect as immediate/accurate as with ODE, leading to the PID controller having to continuously adjust a higher error. Though movements are still too small to see in gzclient.

### Test failure 2. JointTestScrew.ScrewJointForce

The exceeded tolerances are not that high (max 0.0036 on my system, tolerance is set to 1e-08), and seem to only affect the position, not the rotation. Maybe just allowing a higher tolerance for DART in this test will suffice? Though it could be an issue related to the other two test failures.

### Test failure 3. JointTestScrew.WrapAngle

The velocity error starts off small but adds up significantly over time. This consequently affects the error in the angle as well after an initial delay. This could maybe be related to test failure 1 as it seems to be related to setting the force. It seems to be applying too much force as the velocity increases faster than expected.
values.title: Dart 6

summary.raw:
Changes required to run Gazebo with DART 6.

There are still 3 test failures related to DART which may need to be addressed or skipped for DART. The test failures don't seem to suggest anything too severe, but they point out some inaccuracies. This PR is a place to discuss what to do with these tests.

### Test failure 1. JointForceTorqueTest.GetForceTorqueWithAppliedForce (and same for JointForceTorqueTest.GetForceTorqueWithAppliedForceReset)

The cubes are meant to be "held up" by the force set to the joints. When viewing with gzclient, the behaviour is exactly the same as with ODE, it's working as expected. However the force and torque of wrench01 fluctuate quite significantly ([-35..35], sometimes more or less), while they are expected to fluctuate only in the range [-2..2].  The fluctuations aren't smooth, they sometimes incur large jumps between iterations.

Maybe the DART reaction to setting the force does not have an effect as immediate/accurate as with ODE, leading to the PID controller having to continuously adjust a higher error. Though movements are still too small to see in gzclient.

### Test failure 2. JointTestScrew.ScrewJointForce

The exceeded tolerances are not that high (max 0.0036 on my system, tolerance is set to 1e-08), and seem to only affect the position, not the rotation. Maybe just allowing a higher tolerance for DART in this test will suffice? Though it could be an issue related to the other two test failures.

### Test failure 3. JointTestScrew.WrapAngle

The velocity error starts off small but adds up significantly over time. This consequently affects the error in the angle as well after an initial delay. This could maybe be related to test failure 1 as it seems to be related to setting the force. It seems to be applying too much force as the velocity increases faster than expected.
summary.html:
Changes required to run Gazebo with DART 6.

There are still 3 test failures related to DART which may need to be addressed or skipped for DART. The test failures don't seem to suggest anything too severe, but they point out some inaccuracies. This PR is a place to discuss what to do with these tests.

Test failure 1. JointForceTorqueTest.GetForceTorqueWithAppliedForce (and same for JointForceTorqueTest.GetForceTorqueWithAppliedForceReset)

The cubes are meant to be "held up" by the force set to the joints. When viewing with gzclient, the behaviour is exactly the same as with ODE, it's working as expected. However the force and torque of wrench01 fluctuate quite significantly ([-35..35], sometimes more or less), while they are expected to fluctuate only in the range [-2..2]. The fluctuations aren't smooth, they sometimes incur large jumps between iterations.

Maybe the DART reaction to setting the force does not have an effect as immediate/accurate as with ODE, leading to the PID controller having to continuously adjust a higher error. Though movements are still too small to see in gzclient.

Test failure 2. JointTestScrew.ScrewJointForce

The exceeded tolerances are not that high (max 0.0036 on my system, tolerance is set to 1e-08), and seem to only affect the position, not the rotation. Maybe just allowing a higher tolerance for DART in this test will suffice? Though it could be an issue related to the other two test failures.

Test failure 3. JointTestScrew.WrapAngle

The velocity error starts off small but adds up significantly over time. This consequently affects the error in the angle as well after an initial delay. This could maybe be related to test failure 1 as it seems to be related to setting the force. It seems to be applying too much force as the velocity increases faster than expected.
